title: Blair says Brexit is answer to none of U.K. challenges as he warns Corbyn against backing an election
text:
Brexit is the answer to none of Britain’s challenges Former U.K. Prime Minister Tony Blair

Blair on Monday continued to attack both the idea of Brexit and the ruling Conservative Party, which may take the U.K. out of the European Union on Oct. 31 without an agreed deal.

In a speech to the Institute for Government, Blair said the June 2016 referendum in favor of leaving the EU was not a “mandate for no deal.” A mandate to do should come from either Parliament or another vote, Blair said.

Blair did offer praise for the current Labour leader, Jeremy Corbyn, who he has attacked previously. By not pushing to be a caretaker prime minister, Corbyn “has behaved responsibly, and if he continues to put country first, he will benefit the country and himself.” Blair said a potential general election was a “trap” and Labour should vote against it.

Prime Minister Boris Johnson has pushed through a one-month suspension of U.K. Parliament in a maneuver analysts say is designed to alleviate any potential to thwart a no-deal exit. Johnson may be trying to goad Corbyn into triggering a general election by losing a confidence vote.

Related: Boris Johnson takes aim against opponents of Brexit plans

The British pound GBPUSD, -0.0083% on Monday exchanged hands at $1.2080 vs. a close of $1.2161, and also fell GBPEUR, +0.0182% vs. the euro.
